cleaned_text: its really not its called iconography roman iconography is pretty well studied and i promise you that the person running the study knows it better than you do you not only have to think about what it looks like but why it would be there you also have to think about what it is presenting there are multiple clues that all point towards minerva if i drew a little circle with an arm extended above it and two dots for eyes and a small mustache you would know who it was and wouldnt go it could be anyone with a small mustache hailing a cab we get a lot of signs through iconography as to who is being represented for example if we see someone wearing a lion skin its typically herculesherakles or alexander the great or one of his diadochoi imitating him theres a rare chance that it could be milo of croton but even if you found it in croton i would still take the safe bet of hercules unless his name was literally carved in it there are clues that can help us separate hercules from alexander facial here is a quick one to look for but is not always definitive as hercules can sometimes be shown as clean shaven too the weapon he has is usually a huge indicator hercules usually has a club and alexander usually has armour or is otherwise dressed while hercules is usually nude or scantily clad with minerva theres a chance to confuse her with athena so we have to take in things like where it came from when it was made etc to help distinguish

cleaned_text: yes and no its the equivalent and they have a lot of the same mythology origin skills etc but they are coming through two different cultural lenses and also we have a lot of things happen with mythology where godsgoddessesdemigods can blend together and join characteristics in one cultures system but a similar one in another might keep them separate also you would add different variations of the same deity within that culture or as time goes on they change so minerva in one century might be different from minerva in another or minerva in one place might be different from minerva in another so those both will be different from athena in athens even if sometimes only subtlety so for simplicities sake we can say its athena in rome and if youre not dealing with mythology as part of your studies thats perfectly fine to keep it at that but it is a bit more complicated than that if you really are digging deep also we see a bit of cross cultural exchange where they can sometimes get attributes from different cultures that are added to theirs they didnt copy and paste minerva from the greeks minerva was etruscan as well but some of the mythology associated with athena did become associated with minerva through this joined association

cleaned_text: mars can often be lacking a shield but this isnt always the case but a shield is usually more associated with minerva while the spear and helmet is associated with both he sometimes holds a trophy dedicated after a battle to claim victory though both sides could do so or a cup the next thing to look for is a beard though mars can sometimes be shown as younger especially in older works <url> the use or grip of the spear is one of the distinguishing features though mars usually has it pointed outward as if ready to use it or he has a high grip with the blade pointed down into the ground <url> i dont think i know of any ancient depictions before the rd century ce that show minerva ready to use her spear she would use a thunderbolt as a weapon instead though i have seen coins describe the bolt as a spear which i believe is wrong the grip can sometimes be high like with mars but can also be lower as shown on this ring a bit more relaxed so look for the shield or lack thereof look for the beard or lack thereof look for how the spear is used and held and in more detailed images we would look at clothing and other associated imagery the thunderbolt etc then you look at popularity and the representation minerva as part of the capitoline triad was far more important than mars outside of gaul and was worshipped more widely and in more representations

owners didnt pay slaves that they lacked the ability to pay slaves the money was still there with profits for any capable handler they didnt pay them because they didnt have to <number> slave labour people were generally okay with slavery occurring others kept former slaves many of whom had no place to go and paid them basically nothing to keep doing the same job with some added freedoms others brought in other racial minorities that they could exploit particularly those from china we see this most famously in the railroad building and gold rushes but this also happened in the american south with what we call coolies important note this term is extremely offensive outside of a historical context the us government was aware of coolies being used and they had also been used prior to the war they even tried to ban the practice before the civil war ended but again enforcement is an issue the laws passed in the coming years would basically allow coolies to be used as long as they werent cleaned_text: how did america resolve labor demands after slaves were emancipated youve got like <number> topics in this post and all of them are complicated labor demands varied wildly from place to place and most of it was solved through immigration whether that was immigration internally from state to state as it was post s or whether that was from foreign immigration and whether that immigration was voluntary or forced through enslavement changes over time and over location i dont really remember being taught this in k<number> and even in my college history courses at least not in detail i understand there was an adjustment period where slaves were slowly receiving their freedom after the civil war but how did the government manage to make up for that free labor economically there generally wasnt a governmental policy on labor demand the advent of the administrative state and policies around topics of labor supply wages economic management etc are fairly new there was the period between <number> and <number> and then again between <number> and <number> were there was some federal attempt at regulation of the economy through the st and nd national bank but it was minimal and mostly just addressed monetary policy very primitively and government debt most of what we think of now as economic policy is an invention of the fdr administration and wasnt possible legally until after the famous west coast hotel case this topic involves a combination of complicated state capacity building and the history of the administrative state and a complicated legal history youll often hear of the lochner era of the court and its this pre west coast hotel era when courts had a very strict interpretation of the commerce clause of the constitution most labor regulation was left to the states in the southern states former slave holders enacted a series of laws called black codes that limited freedom of black americans ideas about citizenship were still very much in question states determined citizenship then and most southern states didnt allow for black citizenship that changed in <number> with the passage of the th amendment but it was still a fight usually things like labor contracts and debt forms of social control enslaved people were often forced to take the last names of their enslavers so everyone would know where they were supposed to be working and things like vagrancy laws and prison leasing kept black people stuck in place and limited their ability to find new jobs manisha sinhas new book the rise and fall of the nd republic gets into this a little but there are other complex issues like republican ideas about economic progress in the south that created incentives for large farming concerns and low wage farm laborshare cropping systems that made small hold farming economically unviable was there a meeting where officials came up with a type of programming to solve that problem how did america transition from relying on free labor to developing a social hierarchy dependent upon profession and income i know there were elements of that hierarchy during the slave era but was the gap between the wealthiest and the middle class as significant as it is now there werent officials meeting to come up with solutions to economic problems until fdrs administration because <number> there wasnt an administrative state that could do it and <number> the federal government wasnt legal to really have a national economic policy in the way we think of it today bc of the courts interpretation of the commerce clause i dont know what you mean by free labor exactly but america was probably more hierarchal pre wwii than it is now the passage of flsa and the nlra were key to workers being able to really advocate for improved conditions before that a workers only real option was to leave and labor stability was a huge issue as to information on the wage gap its also very complicated <number> we dont have statistics on national wages that are great before the passage of the th amendment there is some information from the irs before that but they mostly focused on the extremely wealthy and that was only for a short period around the civil war bc of proportional taxation rules in art i of the const there is some census information and some states did a good job but nationally its a hodge podge before <number> <number> wealth was very different pre<number> most peoples wealth was entirely in land especially after the th amendment and the nd largest property class enslaved people suddenly didnt exist bc of that wealth inequality seems less bc enough people owned enough land that they seemed to have similar wealth but income inequality was wildly different most farm laborers made about <cur><number> a month throughout the th century that was a large driver of people quitting farming and getting into wage labor in the growing industrial sector of the economy wealth inequality could be huge with a simple mechanic in the city earning <number> or <number> times what a farm laborer was earning but their wealth might seem similar bc the farm laborer had land and the mechanic did not but at the end of the th century with a real uptick during wwi you get some of the hierarchy you seem to be talking about but it was just a different hierarchy and was probably even less hierarchal as wage labor became more important than land holdings these questions lead me to believe that people in power when faced with this issue somehow managed to develop the concept of the american dreama competitive and seemingly unattainable ideal this was integrated into the culture to draw people in with the promise of free land and upward mobility as we know from history achieving this dream is not as easy as it sounds numerous factors and influences create marginalized groups the reality of this facade is that this core aspect ingrained into americans since birth is genuinely fictionalized the concept of the american dream is complicated its changed significantly over time from a jeffersonian idea of the republican yeoman farmer at the end of the th century into an idea of a pioneering westward moving go getter into an entrepreneur and self made man during the later th and early th century after the frontier closed to something more like it is today that began after the end of wwi before wwi the american dream wasnt extended to everyone it wasnt meant to include non anglo americans initially by the end of the th century german immigrants were included in the idea but not very many other immigrants were by the time of the s it was expanding to irish immigrants by the turn of the century southern europeans and jews were starting to be included and the idea of america as a melting pot was beginning to take shape black people were beginning to be included during wwii as part of the double v campaign mexican americans were able to begin to stake a claim during lbjs administration with his great society program sarah churchwell had a recent book on the subject in the th century called behold america shes got an essay in the catalyst that gives a brief overview of the topic <url>

different sources at different times for jefferson and washington it was in vast estates and the people they enslaved for hamilton it was a robust commercial sector for adams it was a kind of mix of piety civil duty and economic comfort this is very different than what the top was after the us civil war or during the s when the jeffersonian ideal became completely eclipsed and the south became cleaned_text: academic article open access <url> >abstract the initial peopling of south america is a topic of intense archaeological debate among the most contentious issues remain the nature of the humanmegafauna interaction and the possible role of humans along with climatic change in the extinction of several megamammal genera at the end of the pleistocene in this study we present the analysis of fossil remains with cutmarks belonging to a specimen of neosclerocalyptus xenarthra glyptodontidae found on the banks of the reconquista river northeast of the pampean region argentina whose ams c dating corresponds to the last glacial maximum <number> cal ybp paleoenvironmental reconstructions stratigraphic descriptions absolute chronological dating of bone materials and deposits suggest a relatively rapid burial event of the bone assemblage in a semidry climate during a wet season quantitative and qualitative analyses of the cut marks reconstruction of butchering sequences and assessments of the possible agents involved in the observed bone surface modifications indicate anthropic activities our results provide new elements for discussing the earliest peopling of southern south america and specifically for the interaction between humans and local megafauna in the pampean region during the last glacial maximum

of racial issues but a lot of other things like labor rights and social welfare issues tie into the shift of urban constituencies basically the dem party had a few major constituencies a big one was southern political power holders but the other really important one is the urban political party bosses that could turn out large numbers of voters tammany hall is kind of the prebollweevil example that most people are familiar with these urban bosses maintained their political power by turning out large numbers of working class and urban poor to vote they did this by giving out aid and creating jobs and patronage a lot of this was very corrupt but it still generated a lot of economic benefits that the party could control in the s the us started getting bollweevil infestations that were destroying cotton crops it made share cropping that was already untenable economicallly for the share croppers impossible so you start getting a migration from the south to the north of black americans they are shut out of farming bc they cant afford land so they get jobs in urban settings in factories a lot of northern businesses actively recruited them as a counterbalance to growing labor power henry ford did a lot of this but as these people move north they get incorporated into the democrats urban political machines its not a smooth process you have people like wilson who fight against it within the party but by the time you get to fdr in places like new york detroit chicago and cincinnatti black americans are an important part of the dem urban coalition and you see fdr having to thread this line between his southern coalition partners and demands from his northern urban coalition partners fdr starts making reforms that can do both things all war housing thats built is segregated but bc of the work of a philip randolph and his threat of a march on washington fdr issued exec order <number> which prohibited discrimination in hiring for defense industry jobs <url> black americans also launched the double v campaign that very much tied the us civil rights movement to the victory in wwii and drew clear comparison to the lack of democracy in the us this put a lot of pressure on fdr bc of the obvious hypocrisy of the us position of making the world safe for democracy when there were frequent racist riots and attacks by white people against black servicemen and black workers in the war industry fdr institutes programs like the black panthers the red tails and the nd inf div by the time of truman you get a reversal of wilson and a desegregation of the military and federal government you still have the feds letting states administer federal programs like the gi bill and the fha that states run in a racist manner banks made sure the fha was administer in a racist manner everywhere in the us up through <number> but all these things were creating a conflict in the dems in <number> you get the split with the dixiecrats many like strom thurmond who would become republicans around the time of goldwaters <number> campaign throughout this entire time basically since the late s when enough black americans were excluded from democracy in the southern states there was a push within the gop to become more openly a party that catered to white interests this faction of the gop was coined the lily white gop you see strong movements in all the southern states to fight what were called the black and tan republicans who wanted a biracial coalition this basically comes to a head in the s with the crm and the civil rights act herbert humpries gave a speech in support of lbj at the <number> dem convention that forced the dems to choose a side they chose civil rights at the same time the gop nominated barry goldwater goldwater pretty openly courted racists with his states rights campaign until too many klansman started showing up at his events at first he tried to play coy it was very much akin to donald trumps initial refusal to reject david dukes endorsement when trump claimed he didnt know who he was goldwater kind of pretended he didnt know about it goldwater campaigned on his opposition to the cra and to brown v board goldwater also violated laws and gop rules by having primaries held in segregated locations to prevent black gop members from participating the san francisco gop convention is famous for its open racist hostility to their black members this was the turning point for prominent black gop members like jackie robinson black delegates talked about being spit on and having their feet stomped on people like rockefeller and george romney who spoke about rejecting the klan and john birch society members were heckled in light of what was going on throughout the south at this time white racial attacks were playing out on tv almost every night bc bull connor had just left office the year before goldwater lost opposition to school integration was still strong places like prince edwards county in va had shut down its entire school system instead of integrate and kept it shut down for <number> years not reopening until <number> the dems leaned into civil rights after that with lbj passing <number> major civil rights bills the <number> cra that outlawed segregation in public accommodations the vra and the <number> fair housing act that ended redlining and housing discrimination nixon was able to exploit white resentment about this and you see a lot of experimentation among leaders about how to address this with things like the william f buckley campaign for mayor in <number> and daleys response to mlks failed northern campaign in chicago nixon was able to figure out how to rally disaffected white voters on a number of causes like crime and protesting groups as a whole this was the height of anti vietnam war protesting and left wing violence like the sla and the weatherman and the civil rights movement ken phillips died last year in the fall and there are a ton of national party the gop is somewhat stuck as a regional southern and rural party and tied to white resentment but whether he was successful or not in his goals to make a national party with broad cleaned_text: well theres lots of ways one could go about this the men were of two different political parties and two separate political movements ill briefly skim just some of the ways the differences should be understood bryan was a populist which was popular with western farmers and his nomination as the democrat presidential candidate was kind of like if bernie sanders had won the <number> primary in terms of impact a lot of the stuff the populists were pursuing was for the relief of western farmers the most famous of their policies would be bimetalism where they pursued basing american currency off of a gold and a silver standard this would increase the money supply and also lead to inflation as more money poured into the system producers such as american farmers supported inflationary politics because it meant they could sell their produce at higher costs and then use that money to pay off their bank loans banks were opposed to this because they would lose out on the loan repayments with inflation causing them to be worth less than they wouldve been when issued hence the bryan v mckinley election was viewed as one of populist antieconomic policies vs the party of big business and prosperity theres other famous populist policies such as direct election of senators but the money debate is probably the most famous william jenning bryans legendary cross of gold speech was about the gold vs bimetallist currency debate la follette was a bit of a populist in his own right but he was associated more with the progressives progressives were technocrats associated with alleviating the contradictions and oppression of capitalism through government reform while a populist would turn to the people and rile up the crowd about how unfair banks are a progressive would be someone more likely to pull out charts and evidence and describe the exact detailed policy that would appease farmers without having to antagonize banks its a rather subtle distinction that i hope i am getting across but it is fascinating imo if one wanted to you could draw the comparison between bidens presidency as a progressive one rather than a populist one that people expected out of a bernie presidency i would caution against going too far with that analogy since these are two very different political and social contexts but it may help give you an idea both the populists and progressives as the left wings of liberalism would occasionally have support from socialists and other anticapitalist movements even if the solutions either group would pursue would have subtle but important differences to give one last example a populist would want to improve peoples lives by putting more power and money in the hands of common everyday farmers while progressives would want to improve peoples lives by reducing tariffs to decrease prices and legislating quality of life improvements such as government sanitation and health programs

cleaned_text: well let me start by putting it this way it wasnt that the parties themselves switched so much as the populations they represented changed the united states doesnt have real political parties as they exist anywhere else in the world instead they operate as loose confederations of different state parties that come together and endorse specific candidates a candidate is not beholden to any sort of actual party discipline and thus the parties have only recently become more ideologically driven and a lot of issues we seen in political discourse since the <number>s is that party leadership is still pulling on these old levers that dont really do anything anymore so to take that apart a bit more if we were to look at say <number>s<number>s you would find conservative and progressive wings in both parties the labels arent exact and should be understand as posthoc classifications like most historical labels are im going to pause a moment to get into how the two parties should be understood in order to understand their left and right wings the republicans had their origin in the collapse of the whigs in the late antebellum period and they arose as a sort of procapital and probusiness party ranging from the small scale quasilassallism of yeoman frontier farmers represented by the likes of lincoln and the protocapitalists who would emerge as the great winners of the american civil war the progressive wing of the republicans came more from that whiglincoln tradition that believed more in empowering the individual through access to the land and the governments task of helping to build a society such men could thrive in the conservative wing was more overtly capitalist in its interest you could view teddy roosevelt as coming from that progressive left wing of the party but william mckinley and calvin coolidge came from that conservative right wing of the party cont
label: r/history

cleaned_text: the democrats however were older and dated back to the second generation of american political leadership chiefly andrew jackson and martin van buren they were the party of the common white man through the former with all of the social conservatism and racism that entailed and the party of the political machine through the latter that is how democrats also came to be associated as the party of white immigrants since those populations would make up key voting blocs of their political machine the progressive movement in both parties arose from the contradictions and horrors of capitalist development in the postcivil war gilded age the arguments used and even the policies pursued would differ between democrat and republican progressives but the basic idea of trying to improve the ills of society through technocratic legal management directed by highly educated intellectuals and academics was more or less the common goal the conservative republicans the more overtly probusiness wing would have their heyday in the interwar period of the <number>s and <number>s in the presidencies of harding coolidge and hoover although hoover is a bit more of an interesting case they would fall out of favor in the aftermath of the great depression and the rise of new deal politics the new deal coalition brought progressive energies mostly into the democratic party under the leadership of the elder progressive fdr the party machine itself eventually adopted fdrs progressivism as seen two later political leaders who were party men harry truman and lbj versus fdr who was a classical progressive and jfk who was an idealistic rich kid the conservative republicans would strike back against the progressives in <number> and the rise of movement conservatism most closely associated with barry goldwater as the democrats alienated their conservative faction with the civil rights movement of the <number>s it led to the conservatives coalescing into the republican party under nixon in the <number>s as a reaction to the <number>s and then more completely under reagan in the victory of conservative neoliberalism over socialism and keynesian progressivism in the cleaned_text: hi as we hope you can appreciate the holocaust can be a fraught subject to deal with while we dont want to curtail discussion we also remain very conscious that threads of this nature can attract the very wrong kind of responses and it is an unfortunate truth that on reddit outright holocaust denial can often rear its ugly head as such the rhistory mods have created this brief overview it is not intended to stifle further discussion but simply lay out the basic incontrovertible truths to get them out of the way what was the holocaust the holocaust refers to the genocidal deaths of <number><number> million european jews carried out systematically by nazi germany as part of targeted policies of persecution and extermination during world war ii some historians will also include the deaths of the roma communists mentally disabled and other groups targeted by nazi policies which brings the total number of deaths to <number><number> million debates about whether or not the holocaust includes these deaths or not is a matter of definitions but in no way a reflection on dispute that they occurred but this guy says otherwise unfortunately there is a small but vocal minority of persons who fall into the category of holocaust denial attempting to minimize the deaths by orders of magnitude impugn well proven facts or even claim that the holocaust is entirely a fabrication and never happened although they often selfstyle themselves as revisionists they are not correctly described by the title while revisionism is not inherently a dirty word actual revision to quote michael shermer entails refinement of detailed knowledge about events rarely complete denial of the events themselves and certainly not denial of the cumulation of events known as the holocaust it is absolutely true that were you to read a book written in <number> or so you would find information which any decent scholar today might reject and that is the result of good revisionism but these changes which even can be quite large such as the reassessment of deaths at auschwitz from ~<number> million to ~<number> million are done within the bounds of respected academic study and reflect decades of work that builds upon the work of previous scholars and certainly does not willfully disregard documented evidence and recollections there are still plenty of questions within holocaust studies that are debated by scholars and there may still be more out there for us to discover and revise but when it comes to the basic facts there is simply no valid argument against them so what are the basics beginning with their rise to power in the s the nazi party headed by adolf hitler implemented a series of antijewish policies within germany marginalizing jews within society more and more stripping them of their wealth livelihoods and their dignity with the invasion of poland in <number> the number of jews under nazi control reached into the millions and this number would again increase with the invasion of the soviet union in <number> shortly after the invasion of poland the germans started to confine the jewish population into squalid ghettos after several plans on how to rid europe of the jews that all proved unfeasible by the time of the invasion of the soviet union in <number> ideological antisemitism and pragmatic resources considerations lead to masskillings becoming the only viable option in the minds of the nazi leadership first only practiced in the ussr it was influential groups such as the ss and the administration of the general government that pushed to expand the killing operations to all of europe and sometime at the end of <number> met with hitlers approval the early killings were carried out foremost by the einsatzgruppen paramilitary groups organized under the aegis of the ss and tasked with carrying out the mass killings of jews communists and other undesirable elements in the wake of the german militarys advance in what is often termed the holocaust by bullet the einsatzgruppen with the assistance of the wehrmacht the sd the security police as well as local collaborators would kill roughly two million persons over half of them jews most killings were carried out with mass shootings but other methods such as gas vans intended to spare the killers the trauma of shooting so many persons day after day were utilized too by early <number> the final solution to the socalled jewish question was essentially finalized at the wannsee conference under the direction of reinhard heydrich where the plan to eliminate the jewish population of europe using a series of extermination camps set up in occupied poland was presented and met with approval construction of extermination camps had already begun the previous fall and mass extermination mostly as part of operation reinhard had began operation by spring of <number> roughly <number> million persons nearly all jewish men women and children were immediately gassed upon arrival at bezec sobibor and treblinka over the next two years when these reinhard camps were closed and razed more victims would meet their fate in additional extermination camps such as chemno but most infamously at auschwitzbirkenau where slightly over <number> million persons mostly jews died under the plan set forth at wannsee exterminations were hardly limited to the jews of poland but rather jews from all over europe were rounded up and sent east by rail like cattle to the slaughter although the victims of the reinhard camps were originally buried they would later be exhumed and cremated and cremation of the victims was normal procedure at later camps such as auschwitz the camps there were two main types of camps run by nazi germany which is sometimes a source of confusion concentration camps were well known means of extrajudicial control implemented by the nazis shortly after taking power beginning with the construction of dachau in <number> political opponents of all type not just jews could find themselves imprisoned in these camps during the prewar years and while conditions were often brutal and squalid and numerous deaths did occur from mistreatment they were not usually a death sentence and the population fluctuated greatly although concentration camps were later made part of the final solution their purpose was not as immediate extermination centers some were way stations and others were work camps where germany intended to eke out every last bit of productivity from them through what was known as extermination through labor jews and other undesirable elements if deemed healthy enough to work could find themselves spared for a time and allowed to toil away like slaves until their usefulness was at an end although some concentration camps such as mauthausen did include small gas chambers mass gassing was not the primary purpose of the camp many camps becoming extremely overcrowded nevertheless resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of inhabitants due to the outbreak of diseases such as typhus or starvation all of which the camp administrations did little to prevent bergenbelsen which was not a work camp but rather served as something of a way station for prisoners of the camp systems being moved about is perhaps one of the most infamous of camps on this count saw some <number> deaths caused by the conditions often located in the reich camps liberated by the western forces were exclusively concentration camps and many survivor testimonies come from these camps the concentration camps are contrasted with the extermination camps which were purpose built for mass killing with large gas chambers and later on crematoria but little or no facilities for inmates often they were disguised with false facades to lull the new arrivals into a false sense of security even though rumors were of course rife for the fate that awaited the deportees almost all arrivals were killed upon arrival at these camps and in many cases the number of survivors numbered in the single digits such as at bezec where only seven jews forced to assist in operation of the camp were alive after the war several camps however were hybrids of both types the most famous being auschwitz which was vast a complex of subcamps the infamous selection of prisoners conducted by ss doctors upon arrival meant life or death with those deemed unsuited for labor immediately gassed and the more healthy and robust given at least temporary reprieve the death count at auschwitz numbered around <number> million but it is also the source of many survivor testimonies how do we know running through the evidence piece by piece would take more space than we have here but suffice to say there is a lot of evidence and not just the mountains of survivor testimony we have testimonies and writings from many who participated as well german documentation of the programs this site<url> catalogs some of the evidence we have for mass extermination as it relates to auschwitz below youll find a short list of excellent works that should help to introduce you to various aspects of holocaust study third reich trilogy<url> by richard evans hitler the germans and the final solution<url> by ian kershaw auschwitz a new history<url> by laurence rees ordinary men<url> by christopher browning denying the holocaust<url> by deborah e lipstadt askhistorians faqraskhistorianswikiwwiiwikinazigermany i am a bot and this action was performed automatically please contact the moderators of this subredditmessa

cleaned_text: im almost done with frances clarke and rebecca jo plants of age boy soldiers and military power in the civil war era it won the gilder lehrman lincoln prize for <number> the prize winners are always good so i shouldnt really be surprised thats its good but its still such an impressive work that at least once a chapter they add something novel and important to the field this work will probably fly under the radar of most of the legal field especially in pcr work but it has a lot of important new information on habeas corpus jurisprudence that needs to be followed up i was also surprised to learn about their efforts to count underage soldiers in both armies and their conclusion that underage soldiers were at least as prevalent in the union army as the confederates their argument is compelling and based on their survey numbers and their supporting records of petitions to the war dept and legal cases along with social data like reporting and proposed legislation i think their hypothesis is well supported the book also does a good job at looking at the social change this created in both the north and south of the us and reset adultchild relationships in a way that fundamentally set the us up for an increasingly industrialized economy i think this is going to be one of those books that creates a sea change in the historiography of th century america and would recommend it about as strongly as possible

cleaned_text: finished the books ive been reading over the previous weeks one i would recommend and one i wouldnt reviews copied from my goodreads berlin portrait of a city through the centuries by rory maclean ><number><number> >it was ok the book covers the history of berlin from around <number> to the present day each of the chapters focuses on an individuals life in the city some of these people are well known while others are very obscure >some of the book is fictionalised so its not all real history which is a big flaw the writing is a bit too flowery and pretentious for my tastes the book is a bit too focused on the arts actors writers etc and not enough on politics for my taste as well >some of the chapters were decent i liked the chapters on marlene dietrich and leni riefenstahl the most there was also a decent one about a loyal communist in east berlin during the cold war >overall i wouldnt recommend it due to some of the book being fictional there are probably better books about the history of berlin out there but this was a book i bought as it was cheap i didnt seek it out so i have nothing to compare it to and vertigo the rise and fall of weimar germany by harald jahner ><number><number> >it is very good the book is well written and just under <number> pages its mainly a socialcultural history of weimar germany with some politics and economics thrown in a lot of the book is about the mood of the time and how the various crises of the weimar republic made people feel the hatred seething in returning wwi soldiers who joined the freikorps the moral decline and confusion caused by hyperinflation in <number> apathy from unemployment or fear of unemployment driving remaining workers towards the nazis >normally im not that interested in cultural history the arts i mean but i thought this book did the topic as well as the arts are tied into the wider vibe of the weimar republic and the political debates of the time for example in the architecture chapter it mentions a pretty silly culture war of the day between people who preferred flat roofs or pointy roofs nationalists and conservatives tended to prefer pointy tying the arts and culture to wider society and politics meant chapters on topics i normally have no interest in like dancing worked well imo >there was an interesting chapter later on in the book about the change in mood following the great depression it basically says that the cultural progressivenessmodernity of the weimar era was in retreat well before the nazis took over dances and music became more slower traditional womens hair cuts mostly reverted to pres styles longer skirts etc the nazi bans on things like jazz were targeting things that were already in decline in germany >the last sections of the book are more politically focused and cover the failure of the republic and the rise of the nazis >the book isnt that heavy on statistics or policy which i think works in this instance as it is more of a socialcultural history >overall highly recommend it if youre interested in the weimar republic continuing with my bought new german history books im now onto germany <number> by volker ulrich seems good so far but i havent finished the first chapter on the french occupation of the ruhr yet

cleaned_text: the intent of royalaristocratic marriages were to managecement <number> alliances between families dynasties and countries <number> personal economics brides in the past came with dowries and while they were intended to support the wife and children the wealth andor property infusion could come in handy at the right time <number> inheritances keep the titles and lands in the family at all costs when taken to an extreme the above positives got outweighed by the dramatic drop in genetic diversity in a blood line this was one of the reasons that when i taught history to high school freshmen they all learned this mantra dynasties went father to son father to son father to son to moron all i had to do was start them on father to son and they picked it up and quickly identified the moron and the end of the line it didnt always work but it made the point they learned that little ditty starting in ancient egypt and it was starkly shown with those wonderful hapsburg portraits just because mummy and daddy arranged everything it does not mean that the princebaroncountking would always willingly take the young lady in question as his bride probably one of the better known ones was the marriage of henry viii and anne flanders mare of cleves to be fair modern interpretations of annes portraits<url> shows her as cutie henry was eventually strongarmed into marrying her to be fair these arranged marriages werent forced marriages you wanted some level of relationship publicly at least between the <number> people and you wanted them to produce an heir once that was done there arewere plenty of examples of playing hot sheet hide the salami as an outlet as long as it was done in private or in a deniable way all was good the families knew the risks with intermarriage as they could see the offspring which is why they tried to go further out on the family limb than next to the trunk but even nd cousin unions can cause some genetic abnormalities

cleaned_text: the discussion centers around the bengal famine and allegations against winston churchill which have become increasingly common and severe particularly highlighted during a panel at churchill college cambridge in <number> these allegations suggest that churchill was responsible for the famine likening him to a mass murderer or war criminal the speaker refutes these claims explaining that the famine was caused by a typhoon in october <number> that disrupted food supply lines and the inability to import rice due to japanese control over key regions they also highlight churchills efforts to seek aid from other countries despite the challenges posed by the ongoing war and japanese submarine threats in the bay of bengal the speaker asserts that while the famine was a tragedy resulting in millions of deaths it is incorrect to accuse churchill of deliberately causing it they emphasize that churchills derogatory remarks about indians which were considered racist do not equate to him wishing harm on them the speaker also addresses accusations of churchills racism contextualizing his views within the eras prevailing beliefs in racial hierarchies they argue that despite these views churchill felt a duty of care to people across the british empire driven by a sense of responsibility stemming from his privileged background the accusations against churchill are framed as both historically inaccurate and part of a broader ideological and political campaign

cleaned_text: afghanistan is often referred to as the graveyard of empires while central asia can be seen as the graveyard of singular nationalist histories the sogdians exemplify this being one of the most significant diasporas in human history rivaling even that of india in the th century ce kabul was ruled by hindu turk shahs to the north across the oxus amu darya river lay a collection of citystates engaged in trade and conflict among them were the sogdians who practiced various religions including buddhism mazdaism zoroastrianism christianity and judaism alongside them were diverse diasporas from central south west and east asia speaking a mix of languages primarily iranic with many indic influences these overlooked groups remind us that the past was a world without borders in the shadow of the kushans to grasp the significance of the sogdians during their peak in the th and th centuries ce we must first understand their earlier obscurity <number> years prior the kushan empire was a dominant force across the gangetic plains afghanistan and parts of xinjiang controlling key trade routes connecting the indian subcontinent to persia the roman empire and distant china overland trade to china involved navigating the perilous taklamakan desert trading through the desert was fraught with risk as noted by historian valerie hansen in the silk roads a new history transactions typically involved highvalue commodities in small quantities yet these could yield substantial profits judith a lerner and thomas wilde emphasize that items like horses from the ferghana valley gemstones from india musk from tibet and furs from the northern steppes were highly sought after in the ancient world historian etienne de la vassiere describes the kushan empire as a brilliant urban civilization that outshone the very mediocre situation of sogdiana roughly corresponding to modernday southwest uzbekistan and eastern tajikistan at that time sogdiana was relatively isolated from the major trade routes leading across the taklamakan desert while kushan merchants thrived in horse trading as far afield as china and southeast asia nevertheless sogdian traders began to integrate into these networks establishing roots in kushan cities while preserving connections to their homeland de la vassiere points out that sogdian graffiti discovered along the karakoram highway built between presentday pakistan and china indicates their settlement in the upper indus river region by the rd century ce one notable piece of graffiti is a sogdian merchants prayer to a local spirit for safe passage to visit his brother these familial networks provided sogdians with access to capital and market insights giving them a competitive edge simultaneously sogdians began to make their mark in china historian xinriu liu highlights in a silk road legacy the spread of buddhism and islam that the earliest buddhist monks in china were sogdians not native indians in the nd and rd centuries ce they worked in china translating texts from sanskrit to chinese de la vassiere adds that buddhism wasnt a dominant force in sogdiana at that time suggesting these sogdian monks were likely from merchant families that had settled in india where they adopted buddhism and sanskrit before moving to china hindu gods in samarkand though the concepts surrounding indian gods are ancient they were never fixed entities various groups worshipped and patronized them influencing their evolution this is evident in buddhism and similarly applies to other contemporary religions including hinduism for instance the kushans portrayed skanda as mahasena meaning great general the sogdians influenced by this kushan environment returned to their cities with a blend of religious traditions that merged local iranic fireworship with new elements preserving a distinct sogdian identity samarkand now in uzbekistan and once the greatest sogdian citystate serves as an example based on the accounts of the famous chinese pilgrim xuanzang liu argues that in samarkand the buddha was honored with processions featuring torches and firebrands by the th century although the kushan empire had fragmented sogdian diaspora networks thrived and grew in influence by the th and th centuries sogdians had become leading foreign traders in china and their distinctive costumes and dance forms gained popularity in the cosmopolitan tang dynasty at the same time there were notable south asian communities in sogdiana with indian monks achieving success in china the wealth of sogdiana is evident in the mansions of affluent merchants adorned with intricate frescoes depicting gods myths and even stories from the panchatantra sogdian interactions with foreign deities mirrored the dynamics of the kushan empire while the kushans adoption of indian gods was driven by the imperial court in sogdiana this was a more decentralized process led by various merchant elites indian conceptions influenced the gods worshipped in sogdiana while kushan influences shaped the deities venerated in india the zoroastrian gods of the sogdians had diverse attributes and the established indian artistic norm of multiple arms and faces provided a framework for their representation in iranian gods in hindu garb art historian frantz grenet cites buddhist sogdian texts mentioning composite deities like brahmazurwan indraadhvagh mahadevawesparkar their iconography primarily influenced by indian models includes traits such as brahmazurwan with a beard indraadhvagh featuring a third eye and mahadevawesparkar having three faces this last deity draws from the ancient kushan composite god oesosiva merging a cosmic wind god with the supreme shiva in panjikent a significant sogdian city in modern tajikistan mahadevawesparkar is depicted blowing a horn emphasizing the connection to wind these cultural exchanges were intricate not as a result of deliberate design but as an organic assimilation process over centuries layers of influences accumulated in various directions grenet argues that some motifs traveled from the gangetic region to kushan contexts before reaching sogdiana consequently thcentury sogdians may not have viewed these motifs or composite deities as indian or foreign to them these representations were simply part of their local context it is only through a modern lens that associates specific religions with singular languages peoples and regions that the sogdian pantheon appears unusual however the silent frescoes of dancing shiva in panjikent and depictions of elephantriding gods battling tigers and leopards in varaksha challenge us to perceive this ancient world beyond nationalist narratives these connections while not reinforcing contemporary notions of superiority or exclusivity enrich our understanding of our ancestors world and by extension our own

cleaned_text: hi it seems like you are talking about the popular but ultimately flawed and false winners write history trope while the expression is sometimes true in one sense well get to that in a bit it is rarely if ever an absolute truth and particularly not in the way that the concept has found itself commonly expressed in popular history discourse when discussing history and why some events have found their way into the history books when others have not simply dismissing those events as the imposed narrative of victors actually harms our ability to understand history you could say that is in fact a somewhat lazy way to introduce the concept of bias which this is ultimately about because whoever writes history is the one introducing their biases to history a somewhat better but absolutely not perfect approach that works better than winners writing history is to say writers write history this is more useful than it initially seems until fairly recently the literate were a minority and those with enough literary training to actually write historical narratives formed an even smaller and more distinct class within that to give a few examples genghis khan must surely go down as one of the great victors in all history but he is generally viewed quite unfavorably in practically all sources because his conquests tended to harm the literary classes similarly the norsemen historically have been portrayed as uncivilized barbarians as the people that wrote about them were the losers whose monasteries got burned down of course writers are a diverse set and so this is far from a magical solution to solving the problems of bias the painful truth is each source simply needs to be evaluated on its own merits this evaluation is something that is done by historians and part of what makes history and why insights about historical events can shift over time this is possibly best exemplified by those examples where victors did unambiguously write the historical sources the spanish absolutely wrote the history of the conquest of central america from <number> and the reports and diaries of various conquistadores and priests are still important primary documents for researchers of the period but victors write the history presupposes that we still use those histories as they intended which is simply not the case it both overlooks the fundamental nature of modern historical methodology and ignores the fact that while victors have often proven to be predominant voices they have rarely proven to be the only voices archaeology numismatics works in translation and other records all allow us at least some insight into the losers viewpoint as does careful analysis of the winners records we know far more about rome than we do about phoenician carthage there is still vital research into carthage as its being a daily topic of conversation on this subreddit testifies to so while its true that the balance between the voices can be disparate that doesnt mean that the winners are the only voice or even the most interesting which is why stating that history is written by the victors and leaving it at that is harmful to the understanding of history and the process of studying history i am a bot and this action was performed automatically please contact the moderators of this subredditmessagecomposeto=rhistory if you have any questions or concerns

cleaned_text: purpose to determine the identity of the prototypical blind man repeatedly described by philosopher john locke <number><number> methods historical books were reviewed results in several works john locke described a studious man he knew who went blind from smallpox at a young age this man struggled to understand visual concepts such as the yellow color of saffron the clarity of the sun or the color of scarlet which the man compared to a trumpet nonconformist minister john troughton <number><number> went blind from smallpox at a young age troughton was a fellow student with locke at oxford university troughtons sermons quoted the exact portions in song of solomon canticles <number><number> and revelations chapter <number> which contain the imagery and the association of the color scarlet with the sound of trumpets found in lockes writings thus lockes comparison of the color scarlet with the sound of trumpets was probably not a description of synesthesia but rather was an attempt of a blind scholar to understand biblical imagery conclusions the struggles of blind nonconformist minister john troughton to understand biblical imagery probably stimulated john locke to ponder what humans can know innately about vision independent of experience

cleaned_text: while there were no formal public education systems in place in the roman empire to specifically target improving literacy among the lower classes there were some efforts to provide education to a broader segment of society one notable initiative was the establishment of schools by wealthy individuals or benefactors in some urban areas these schools though not widespread aimed to provide basic education to children from lowerincome families additionally some emperors such as augustus promoted educational reforms to encourage literacy and learning furthermore certain professions like scribes required literacy skills so some individuals from lower classes would learn to read and write as part of their trade or occupation despite these efforts the overall literacy rates among the lower classes remained significantly lower compared to the elite and upper classes in roman society

cleaned_text: i actually started reading all of linda schieles stuff on the maya back when i was a l i would have weird dreams about civpro if i didnt read something else before bed back when i was in law school podcasts were new and youtube hadnt been invented this is just if youre going to a us law school i know it works a lot differently in the rest of the country i knew i had no intention of learning mayan nahuatl or any of the other languages but i abused lexis nexus to find papers and the school printers to print them and just made binders of stuff i didnt have that hard of time finding time to read it i realized pretty early on that i was just going to be right about center of the bell curve and that only took about ish hours a week i had a hard limit of only reading for an hour per class and as close to the beginning of class as possible to avoid dinking around so i usually organized as many of my classes as possible into tuesday and thursday and worked the other days of the week and read it in my free time i would just get a book at a time find papers see what was cited in the papers and then read more i wasnt studying for a degree it was just for fun but i think you could pretty easily do both if you wanted to after l year most of law school is a waste of time as far as learning useful things that will help you be a lawyer in the future but if your law school is connected with an undergrad institution i would go talk to the professors in anthropology and history dept you could probably audit a class for cheapfree if you wanted to and if not they would probably share the syllabus from any relevant class i ended up just kind of tinkering with mesoamerican stuff bc i went more into the us civil war bc of its implications on the constitution and the impact of reconstructionredemption bc i think that colors everything in the modern us

cleaned_text: as a science nerd i love the indiana jones atmosphere t=<number> in auto transcript<url> > you would see against the night sky or the dark sky of the outer universe silhouetted the ribs the ribs made of wood as thick as a parsiktu vessel of the wreck of the babylonian ark which like the one in the bible came to rest on a mountain speaking as a christian and this would equally apply for a jew or a muslim im aware of the dog whistle effect so am careful of the emotional appeal of the noahs ark story to my subset of the public its still interesting to see how scripture can be used by historians t=<number> in auto transcript<url> > in the cuneiform tablet signature they always said mr soandso son of mr soandso and the dad was called issuru now issuru is the babylonian word for bird now this is rather an interesting thing because we know all about peoples names in mesopotamia they usually meant something intelligible like servant of such and such a god or shes beautiful beyond compare no one is called bird theres no other case of a person called bird its not a very good name so what does that mean you look at this for the first time in the museum case which i hope you will now do and peer through and make out the details you would think ah i see its a sort of birdseye view of the world well i think thats what it is its a birdy birdy family and this is a birdseye view of the known world and what lies beyond it so that gives it a special kind of warmth of understanding because its failings as it were from a cartographical point of view are irrelevant it is not what theyre interested in and its given us a tremendous insight into many aspects of mesopotamian thinking > its also a triumphant demonstration of what happens when you have a very small totally uninformative and useless fragment of dead boring writing that no one can understand and you join it onto something in the collection which is much bigger and a whole new adventure begins all over again regarding the triumphant demonstration im still a little dubious of irving finkels conclusion about the bird and the birds eye view that looks like something from our culture which we are cleaned_text: yes there are notable differences between the theses of brian murareskus the immortality key and john allegros the sacred mushroom and the cross despite both books dealing with the intersection of religious history and psychoactive substances heres a comparison of their key points <number> core thesis john allegro allegros thesis in the sacred mushroom and the cross is that early christianity was originally a secret fertility cult centered around the use of the psychoactive mushroom amanita muscaria he argued that the stories in the bible particularly the new testament are encoded references to mushroombased rituals and that jesus himself was a symbol rather than a historical figure allegros work is largely philological relying on speculative interpretations of ancient languages and etymologies to make his case brian muraresku murareskus thesis in the immortality key is more focused on the broader ancient mediterranean world rather than christianity alone he argues that certain religious practices particularly those associated with the eleusinian mysteries and early christianity involved the use of psychoactive potions which were central to the spiritual experiences of participants murareskus work is rooted in a combination of archaeological evidence ancient texts and modern scientific research <number> approach to evidence john allegro allegros approach is highly speculative and controversial he bases much of his argument on his interpretations of ancient languages particularly sumerian to draw connections between religious terms and psychoactive mushrooms his work has been criticized for its lack of rigorous evidence and for making leaps in logic that many scholars find unsubstantiated brian muraresku muraresku takes a more cautious and interdisciplinary approach he combines classical scholarship modern scientific analysis including chemical residue analysis on ancient artifacts and an exploration of historical texts to build his case his argument is more evidencebased though it still ventures into speculative territory when drawing conclusions about the exact nature of ancient religious practices <number> focus on christianity john allegro allegros work is almost entirely focused on early christianity he argues that christianity itself was fundamentally based on mushroom worship with all of its symbols rituals and narratives being allegories for psychoactive mushroom use brian muraresku while muraresku does discuss early christianity his focus is broader encompassing the religious practices of ancient greece particularly the eleusinian mysteries and their potential influence on early christian rituals he does not claim that christianity was a mushroom cult but rather that certain psychoactive substances played a role in early christian and prechristian religious experiences <number> reception and impact john allegro allegros book was met with widespread criticism from scholars and religious communities alike it damaged his academic reputation and his theories have largely been dismissed by mainstream scholars as highly speculative and lacking credible evidence brian muraresku murareskus book while controversial has been more positively received particularly among proponents of the emerging field of psychedelic studies it has sparked renewed interest in the possible connections between ancient religious practices and psychoactive substances though some scholars remain skeptical of his more speculative claims <number> religious interpretation john allegro allegros thesis is radical in its reinterpretation of christianity effectively arguing that the religion we know today is a misinterpretation or coverup of a psychedelic cult brian muraresku muraresku does not suggest that christianity as a whole is based on psychedelics but rather that these substances may have played a role in specific religious experiences or rites particularly in the context of mystery religions that may have influenced early christian practices in summary while both authors explore the connection between psychoactive substances and religion allegro presents a far more radical and narrowly focused thesis on early christianity grounded in linguistic speculation whereas muraresku takes a broader more evidencebased approach that places early christianity within a wider context of ancient religious practices that may have involved psychoactive substances

cleaned_text: well theres quite a bit to unpack here for one thing witch hunts were not much of medieval thing the malleus was published at the very tail end of the middle ages and most witch hunts were a thing of the early modern period there were some earlier witch hunts and there were witchcraft and other magic accusations against specific people but the witch unts of pop culture mainly happened after the middle ages also it was not a phenomenon throughout europe some areas could really be describes as being ravaged by witch hunts in others it was isolated cases in some ares there were none the holy roman empire or more precisely some of the constituent parts of the holy roman empire experienced extensive witch hunts theres also a lot of cases in the neighbouring areas of switzerland and france many areas in southern europe had much fewer cases scandinavia did have witch hunts but not on the same level and interestingly with a lot more men accused than women britain had some prominent examples but again not on the same scale as the hre theres also famously cases outside europe especially salem of course as to the death toll being comparatively low that does of course depend on what you compare it to the black death or the thrity years war certainly claimed a lot more lives and were talking orders of magnitude here and that is true for a lot of medieval and early modern military conflicts the crusades the hundred years war the english civil war all had a higher death toll that being said this is a comparison between major military campaigns and people essentially burning their next door neighbours out of paranoid fear at this point were asking whether killing <number> people for a completely imagined crime or killing millions in a horrendous military campaign is worse also many of these other catastrophes were part of the background of insecurity and fear that was an important contributor to the witch craze youre right that the role of the church or churches in this is somewhat complicated the rather common depiction in pop cukture of the inquisition burning witches at the stake is indeed not accurate to say the least on the other hand there is clearly an important religious component for example there is hardly any witch hunts in orthodox country and none in muslim controlled areas and this includes christian territories under ottoman rule the official position of the catholic church for most of the middle ages was that there was in fact no such thing as witchcraft as far as i understand it basically because this would imply supernatural power from a source other than god meaning that belief in witchcraft was against church doctrine so you couldnt really accuse someone of witchcraft because that would essentailly mean you held the heretical belief that witchcraft was real and if you really practiced something you believed to be witchcraft your crime was that belief not your magical practices on the other hand the idea of a pact with the devil was already present in augustines writings and was picked up by thomas aquinas so some of the essentail framework for later witch hunts was already present the main task of the inquisition was always rooting out heresy as such they were not terribly interested in witches and might actually not even believe in their existence this actually means that in countriesareas where the inquisition had a lot of influence like for example spain there were very few witchcraft trials on the other hand the author of the malleus maleficarum was an inquisitor albeit one in constant conflict with church authorities so the inquisition was obviously not immune to the ideas which led to the witch craze but it was not a major proponent of those ideas in fact a lot of the trials were not even held in church courts but in secular courts which also means that the willingness of secular authorities to prosecute people for alleged witchcraft was an important factor in determining where witch hunts did or did not happen what makes it obvious at once that witch hunts were not tied to the inquisition in any way is the fact that a lot of witch hunts took place in protestant territories luther calling for the prosecution of witches from the pulpit obviously didnt help there nor did james vi and is fear of witches later on as to further reading back when i did this stuff at uni a good <number> years ago i seem to remember that wolfgang behringers work was rather highly regarded just tried to google whether that is still the case but apparently he has written a very controversial book about the history of climate in the meantime with some rather stupid claims from what i can gather which doesnt say anything about the validiy of his work on witchcraft but pretty makes googling him rather complicated if you want to read up about witchcraft accusations before the major witch hunts mainly as a tool against politically powerful women gemma hollmanns royal witches is a good read richard kieckhefers magic in the middle ages is also useful for a lot of the background story i havent gotten around to reading marion gibsons witchcraft a history in thirteen trials yet but it certainly seems wirth a read as well

cleaned_text: a lot of why didnt technology take off in the americas questions have the same answer it did but locally that applies to agriculture writing early pottery domesticated animals and indeed to metalworking regional civilizations independently invented and developed the technology but it didnt spread or at least not fast enough we know that civilizations in the northern andes had metalworking three thousand years ago and they continued developing the technology throughout the centuries hammering mining smelting quite sophisticated techniques but it took over two millennia for that knowledge to spread to central america when it did the mesoamericans really went hog wild with it metalworking became an important part of mesoamerican societies within a few centuries and by the time the spanish arrived some mesoamericans had already tentatively started using metal tools and weapons similarly people in the great lakes regions had been making copper tools for up to seven thousand years and theres some evidence of people in the pacific northwest making iron tools but the iron tools never spread and the use of copper only spread south to the mississippian region very slowly and never reached mesoamerica and thats a huge difference with the old world the first large scale metalworking in west asia and the balkans happened some seven thousand years ago not that much earlier than in north america but instead of staying local to the region it spreads rapidly the rest of europe uses it within centuries egypt within a millenium india within two millenia so almost immediately you have this broad interwoven network of civilizations exchanging on ideas techniques raw materials and that really helps improve metalworking like britain was famous for its tin deposits its not hard to imagine british civilization independently inventing a use for tin but then what what can you do with just tin not much but instead britain was part of a continental network exchanging goods and ideas and that british tin was used to make bronze all the way in asia and that is the main thing the americas lacked if andean ideas on mining and smelting gold had made its way to mesoamerica in centuries instead of millennia and if great lakes copper tools had made its way to mesoamerica as well and if the combination of the two ideas had made its way back to the andes and the great lakes and back and forth and back and forth then things would have started rolling instead every american civilization needed to invent the techniques independently and only with the materials they had available locally and because of that its use never left the niche it was originally invented for

cleaned_text: > how was the alter stone moved over land or sea try reading the article >> given major overland barriers en route from northeast scotland to salisbury plain marine transport is one feasible option said the lead author anthony clarke of curtin university > but the archaeologist and writer mike pitts who was not involved in the research but whose work on neolithic monuments includes the book how to build stonehenge said he believed it was more likely the stone was dragged overland than floated by sea >> he said if you put a stone on a boat out to sea not only do you risk losing the stone but also nobody can see it instead a land journey perhaps taking many years would engage people en route with the stone becoming increasingly precious as it travels south he added impossible as it may seem today an overland journey was easily within the reach of neolithic technology french here having seen the complicated way they went about transporting the olympic flame to paris id believe anything its reassuring to see how international is the team reaching the conclusion about the stones scottish origin even someone from wales which is sort of a clincher

language customs religion they were not united they were not buddies they were not a state the macedonians worshipping the same gods speaking the same language albeit a dialect which every single
