can attract the very wrong kind of responses and it is an unfortunate truth that on reddit outright holocaust denial can often rear its ugly head as such the rhistory mods have created this brief overview it is not intended to stifle further discussion but simply lay out the basic incontrovertible truths to get them out of the way what was the holocaust the holocaust refers to the genocidal deaths of <number><number> million european jews carried out systematically by nazi germany as part of targeted policies of persecution and extermination during world war ii some historians will also include the deaths of the roma communists mentally disabled and other groups targeted by nazi policies which brings the total number of deaths to <number><number> million debates about whether or not the holocaust includes these deaths or not is a matter of definitions but in no way a reflection on dispute that they occurred but this guy says otherwise unfortunately there is a small but vocal minority of persons who fall into the category of holocaust denial attempting to minimize the deaths by orders of magnitude impugn well proven facts or even claim that the holocaust is entirely a fabrication and never happened although they often selfstyle themselves as revisionists they are not correctly described by the title while revisionism is not inherently a dirty word actual revision to quote michael shermer entails refinement of detailed knowledge about events rarely complete denial of the events themselves and certainly not denial of the cumulation of events known as the holocaust it is absolutely true that were you to read a book written in <number> or so you would find information which any decent scholar today might reject and that is the result of good revisionism but these changes which even can be quite large such as the reassessment of deaths at auschwitz from ~<number> million to ~<number> million are done within the bounds of respected academic study and reflect decades of work that builds upon the work of previous scholars and certainly does not willfully disregard documented evidence and recollections there are still plenty of questions within holocaust studies that are debated by scholars and there may still be more out there for us to discover and revise but when it comes to the basic facts there is simply no valid argument against them so what are the basics beginning with their rise to power in the s the nazi party headed by adolf hitler implemented a series of antijewish policies within germany marginalizing jews within society more and more stripping them of their wealth livelihoods and their dignity with the invasion of poland in <number> the number of jews under nazi control reached into the millions and this number would again increase with the invasion of the soviet union in <number> shortly after the invasion of poland the germans started to confine the jewish population into squalid ghettos after several plans on how to rid europe of the jews that all proved unfeasible by the time of the invasion of the soviet union in <number> ideological antisemitism and pragmatic resources considerations lead to masskillings becoming the only viable option in the minds of the nazi leadership first only practiced in the ussr it was influential groups such as the ss and the administration of the general government that pushed to expand the killing operations to all of europe and sometime at the end of <number> met with hitlers approval the early killings were carried out foremost by the einsatzgruppen paramilitary groups organized under the aegis of the ss and tasked with carrying out the mass killings of jews communists and other undesirable elements in the wake of the german militarys advance in what is often termed the holocaust by bullet the einsatzgruppen with the assistance of the wehrmacht the sd the security police as well as local collaborators would kill roughly two million persons over half of them jews most killings were carried out with mass shootings but other methods such as gas vans intended to spare the killers the trauma of shooting so many persons day after day were utilized too by early <number> the final solution to the socalled jewish question was essentially finalized at the wannsee conference under the direction of reinhard heydrich where the plan to eliminate the jewish population of europe using a series of extermination camps set up in occupied poland was presented and met with approval construction of extermination camps had already begun the previous fall and mass extermination mostly as part of operation reinhard had began operation by spring of <number> roughly <number> million persons nearly all jewish men women and children were immediately gassed upon arrival at bezec sobibor and treblinka over the next two years when these reinhard camps were closed and razed more victims would meet their fate in additional extermination camps such as chemno but most infamously at auschwitzbirkenau where slightly over <number> million persons mostly jews died under the plan set forth at wannsee exterminations were hardly limited to the jews of poland but rather jews from all over europe were rounded up and sent east by rail like cattle to the slaughter although the victims of the reinhard camps were originally buried they would later be exhumed and cremated and cremation of the victims was normal procedure at later camps such as auschwitz the camps there were two main types of camps run by nazi germany which is sometimes a source of confusion concentration camps were well known means of extrajudicial control implemented by the nazis shortly after taking power beginning with the construction of dachau in <number> political opponents of all type not just jews could find themselves imprisoned in these camps during the prewar years and while conditions were often brutal and squalid and numerous deaths did occur from mistreatment they were not usually a death sentence and the population fluctuated greatly although concentration camps were later made part of the final solution their purpose was not as immediate extermination centers some were way stations and others were work camps where germany intended to eke out every last bit of productivity from them through what was known as extermination through labor jews and other undesirable elements if deemed healthy enough to work could find themselves spared for a time and allowed to toil away like slaves until their usefulness was at an end although some concentration camps such as mauthausen did include small gas chambers mass gassing was not the primary purpose of the camp many camps becoming extremely overcrowded nevertheless resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of inhabitants due to the outbreak of diseases such as typhus or starvation all of which the camp administrations did little to prevent bergenbelsen which was not a by the conditions often located in the reich camps liberated by the western forces were exclusively concentration camps and many survivor testimonies come from these camps the concentration camps are contrasted with the extermination camps which were purpose built for mass killing with large gas chambers and later on crematoria but little or no facilities for inmates often they were disguised with false facades to lull the new arrivals into a false sense of security even though rumors were of course rife for the fate that awaited the deportees almost all arrivals were killed upon arrival at these camps and in many cases the number of survivors numbered in the single digits such as at bezec where only seven jews forced to assist in operation of the camp were alive after the war several camps however were hybrids of both types the most famous being auschwitz which was vast a complex of subcamps the infamous selection of prisoners conducted by ss doctors upon arrival meant life or death with those deemed unsuited for labor immediately gassed and the more healthy and robust given at least temporary reprieve the death count at auschwitz numbered around <number> million but it is cleaned_text: while india wasnt a single political entity it was a little more complicated that kingdoms at war with each other youre not wrong at a basic level that the subcontinent was several kingdoms jostling for regional and trans regional power the video is right about this as well but there was a broader political and sovereign framework that they operated within that had been deeply structured by the mughals there was a shared sense of an entity within which they all existed and one of the best gauges of this is how different kingdoms recognized the nominal sovereignty of the mughals as a means to exercise legitimacy hyderabad awadh bengal the jaipur kingdom all continued to seek nominal status within the mughal state even though the mughal emperors actual political power was significantly constrained mysore would similarly try to seek mughal recognition and when it failed due to the objections of hyderabad they declared themselves sultans but that lack of legitimacy also undermined their ability to hold power and their conflict with the british eventually toppled them the british were able to displace tipu sultan far more easily than many other royal families the marathas are the slightly odd element in this and in part because maratha history has become deeply enmeshed with nationalistic and sectarian memories so the modern vision is of the marathas as hindu rulers looking to overthrow the alien muslim mughal empire almost all of it a th century framing while the marathas did claim imperial status under the chattrapatis their grand imperial claims only really lasted a few years under shivaji and his son after the death of sambhaji power shifted to the peshwai and the maratha clans and these people were perfectly happy to recognize both the chattrapati a title that was incidentally contested between two families at satara and kolhapur due to a disputed succession and the mughals famously for instance in the late th century mahadji shinde was actually one of the strongest supporters of the mughal emperor shah alam and held the position of grand vizier the east india company operated in the same way too the eic had formally sought broad recognition from the mughal empire so that they could operate in the subcontinent it was crucial to gain legitimacy and acceptance in the eyes of indian elites whose collaboration they needed after <number> they received formal status as the diwans of bengal which was still nominally a subordinate to the mughal empire they would pay their national tribute and engage in the rituals of subordination throughout the th century things only really shifted after <number> as parliament forced the company to assert british sovereignty and more imperialist minded governors such as wellesley at the turn of the century pushed the company onto a trajectory of aggressive growth by conquest that the companys directors didnt really want the company slowly and surreptitiously began to drop their references to mughal sovereignty though it did have a destabilizing effect for them this tension over the sovereignty of the empire was one of the major strains of conflict in the great uprising of <number> and while the event was largely recast by the british as indians rebelling against them historians in the th century have pointed out that while that was defacto true in a dejure sense the british were technically the rebels against mughal suzerainty another fun fact the british refusing to pay what was owed to the emperor created a legal dispute that akbar shah actually won as a technical matter he had dispatched raja rammohan roy to england to argue his case and parliament was infact forced to acknowledge that the emperors case was valid and ordered the company to pay the emperor what he was owed they just chose to not really enforce the order and roy died soon after in london and so couldnt press the matter especially with parliament soon ending the companys commercial interests in <number> the point of all of this is to really say that there was infact this thing that the british called the empire of india which everyone sort of operated in its not quite a country but it was a sort of shared political sandbox and gaining formal legitimacy within that imperial frame was important even if the emperors power was purely symbolic but symbolic power can still be important in the study of history and politics even after <number> the british couldnt really escape that imperial construct and ended up recreating it by making victoria its empress and the need to respect the systems and demands of that imperial system and needing to operate as a subordinate within it even if only in a symbolic capacity has had a pretty profound impact on the underlying legal structures that would shape south asian law and the unified political entity that was british india

cleaned_text: the british did formally rule over most of the subcontinent by <number> but the complex system of sovereign authority and symbolism was deeply embedded into the structures of power and in shaking that system the british contributed to the rising of <number> and the way it played out before i explain further i think its important to clarify something major here which is this idea that indians understood the british were here to stay that comment and the underlying assumption of indians seeing themselves as insiders and the british as outsiders is grounded in a vision of united indians and foreign british that was in many ways a construct of the late th and early th century having forged a united country the british were left with the consequence of people actually starting to believe in the joint identity the national movement of the th century played a major role in deepening this dichotomy too but for the most part that sense of a singular national identity didnt exist in the th and early th century people saw the british as simply one more force in their world not necessarily as inherent outsiders but coming back to symbolism the system of claims that british power was built on allowed them to keep indian elites conciliated vast portions of india were under british authority but its worth remembering that the number of britons in india was always small for the raj to work the british needed the local aristocracy and upper caste communities to also accept their rule the vast majority of their army consisted of indian troops most of whom were recruited from upper caste and upper class muslim and hindu peasant communities communities that needed to be reassured that the british were legitimate rulers as any ruler needed to reassure them the other factor in this are the native princes and the local aristocrats essentially groups such as the various talukhdars and zamindars throughout india these groups similarly had to be constantly conciliated and the way the british did this was by notionally demonstrating their enmeshment into the lines of symbolic power rather than imposing themselves as conquerors by <number> this was in crisis the british had been busy alienating both their sepoys and the native princes through controversies over pay policies such as the doctrine of lapse and the anglicization of government the growing feeling among the landed elite was this sense that the british no longer adhered to the ancient customs by which they had lived remember this sort of thinking was not just about feeling hurt over sentiment the idea of customary practice was one that had legal force in many ways british actions were akin to a modern government trampling long held constitutional rights a deeply antagonistic thing for people we see controversies in <number> emerge out of these feelings such as the widespread rumor that the british were going to make muslim and hindu soldiers lose caste by having them bite the enfield bullet cartridges supposedly made of pork and beef these rumors grew out of this sense of alienation when the great revolt broke out sepoys and aristocrats converged on the traditional symbolic powers of the subcontinent bahadur shah zafar in delhi nana saheb the legal peshaw in kanpur the various clan princes such as in gwalior the seat of the shinde clan though the shinde royals ultimately sided with the british having to run from their own troops who were acclaiming them even lakshmibais battles are a manifestation of this all of these groups had been demanding a restoration of their traditional rights and privileges which the british had been undermining as they asserted their own sovereignty over the more traditional lines of power the british would claim these acts rebellious british historiography would write of bahadur shahs proclamation as emperor but nobody was proclaiming him emperor he was already emperor it wasnt until the s that people started going well technically the british were the rebels you know the fact that the eic was defacto in charge of the country doesnt take away from the fact that these equations and claims of symbolic power were important even though the uprising was quelled the british realized they had gone too far in uprooting traditional systems of power post <number> there was a concentrated restoration of native authority the autonomy of native princes such as the nizam of hyderabad and the rajas of gwalior actually increased somewhat the british also eventually realized theyd need to do more hence why the british began investing heavily in trying to promote a veneration of the monarchy indian princes were inculcated into british symbolic recognition through the star of india and later the order of the british empire victoria was proclaimed empress the british would hold grand durbars evoking the old forms of mughal power invest in magnificent architectural projects see the high court buildings the viceregal palaces later things such as victoria memorial and finally new delhi building grand structures was a particularly traditional way of establishing legitimacy in india going back to the establishment of great temples grand mosques and lavish tombs such as the taj mahal the jama masjids in various cities or the great temples in the south you can even see the eventual relocation of the capital to delhi as a manifestation of this policy of keeping the indian elite conciliated and the consequences of these systems of legitimacy sovereignty and conciliation have shaped indian laws and ideas of politics at a deeply fundamental level even today

cleaned_text: so the history of landlords in pakistan is a tad complicated <number> certainly played a small role in the reorganization of holdings there but both sindh and punjab had been relatively recently conquered when the great revolt happened as a result because the region was under much heavier military occupation the uprising wasnt particularly widespread there it is where the myth of a loyal punjab came from sindh similarly didnt see too much pressure what that meant was that landlords werent actively displaced in the same numbers as they were in places such as modern day up and bihar in india but many land holders in pakistan nonetheless gained their domains later in the th century the british played a major role in redistributing land there for instance with the canal colonies in punjab saw significant land tenure expansions and entire communities being established further because the british liked to recruit from peasant communities and because punjab and to an extent sindh became favored recruiting grounds for the army after <number> till about <number> there was also a lot of enmeshment between the major landholders and the military this meant that the british were somewhat invested in making sure communities that they favored as martial races had access to territory so that there was adequate recruitment for the military youll notice i havent spoken much about the nwfp and balochistan and thats because im just not as familiar with those regions they were brought under british rule even later than sindh and punjab for the most part and its outside my area of expertise so i dont want to offer comments on what was going on there vis landlords in relation to the midth century upheavals

cleaned_text: hawke is perhaps most famous for colliding with titanics twin sister olympic in september <number> the two ships were on parallel tracks in the solent when the hawke suddenly turned towards olympic hawke was unable to stop and her armoured bow crashed into the side of olympic causing serious damage to the liner but no injuries hawke suffered major damage with her bow crushed and could have been lost but she was able to make it to port olympic returned to southampton to offload passengers and make emergency repairs but she had to return to her makers at harland and wolff in belfast for drydocking and the replacement of a propellor shaft crews who were busy completing her sister ship were diverted to fixing olympic which meant there were delays to the completion of titanic six weeks of repairs created massive costs for white star who were already spending heavily on the three new super liners and had to find replacement vessels to fill their service ironically the fact olympic survived the collision and flooding of two of her compartments only increased public perceptions that these giant new ships were entirely safe the royal navy blamed olympic for the accident which was held up by the court of inquiry blaming the enormous displacement of water around the liner for drawing in the much smaller warship the case eventually went all the way to the house of lords who ruled against white star though i cant see what punishment the company received anyone

cleaned_text: india in <number> had a larger gdp than all of europe combined measuring historical gdp is notoriously tricky but this is almost certainly false using the figures i can find it seems like it was only slightly larger than western europe so including eastern and southeastern europe indias economy would have been smaller i have a hunch that whoever came up with this fact just ignored the ottoman and russian empires because theyre mostly asian powers even though they had large holdings in europe at that time by <number> indias share had dropped to <number> and its people were left impoverished very cleverly worded to make you think that indias economy had gone down in the intervening years in fact indias gdp overall rose significantly during that period the percentage of world gdp dropped because europe and north america saw an explosion in population and production its like saying americas share of world gdp has dropped since the s because china has been looting the american economy with unfair trade deals chinas trade policies aside the american economy hasnt gone down its just that formerly impoverished countries like china korea and even india to an extent have seen a massive increase in wealth during this period of disorder the british sensed opportunity the british couldnt have cared less about conquering india during the mid th century much like the conquistadors the men who set up britains early territorial gains in india werent operating under orders from home and sometimes completely in the face of them robert clive didnt have the full support of his superiors in the east india company never mind the government in london armies are expensive and the profitminded company men always grumbled about the cost its really ridiculous once you know a bit about the history of the british raj just how close it came to never happening because all they really wanted to do was buy tea then once clive had secured bengal and they realized there was something there worth defending the government in london started to take an interest but even then most of the wars were reactive trying to defend what theyd already taken from ambitious indian princes and the french especially the french who were a lot more interested in playing the game and somehow a lot worse at it indias native institutions were demolished almost half of the raj was made up of autonomous states governed by native princes the british dictated their external affairs but otherwise they could rule themselves although many leaned heavily on the british for support and ironically the video uses a picture of a temple to illustrate the point when indias hindu temples flourished during the raj in fact indias native institutions were far more stable during british rule than they had been under the mughals due to both the disorder of the final decades of mughal power and the very antihindu policies of many emperors and thats just the first minute and a half im not going to go through the whole video

cleaned_text: hi as we hope you can appreciate the holocaust can be a fraught subject to deal with while we dont want to curtail discussion we also remain very conscious that threads of this nature can attract the very wrong kind of responses and it is an unfortunate truth that on reddit outright holocaust denial can often rear its ugly head as such the rhistory mods have created this brief overview it is not intended to stifle further discussion but simply lay out the basic incontrovertible truths to get them out of the way what was the holocaust the holocaust refers to the genocidal deaths of <number><number> million european jews carried out systematically by nazi germany as part of targeted policies of persecution and extermination during world war ii some historians will also include the deaths of the roma communists mentally disabled and other groups targeted by nazi policies which brings the total number of deaths to <number><number> million debates about whether or not the holocaust includes these deaths or not is a matter of definitions but in no way a reflection on dispute that they occurred but this guy says otherwise unfortunately there is a small but vocal minority of persons who fall into the category of holocaust denial attempting to minimize the deaths by orders of magnitude impugn well proven facts or even claim that the holocaust is entirely a fabrication and never happened although they often selfstyle themselves as revisionists they are not correctly described by the title while revisionism is not inherently a dirty word actual revision to quote michael shermer entails refinement of detailed knowledge about events rarely complete denial of the events themselves and certainly not denial of the cumulation of events known as the holocaust it is absolutely true that were you to read a book written in <number> or so you would find information which any decent scholar today might reject and that is the result of good revisionism but these changes which even can be quite large such as the reassessment of deaths at auschwitz from ~<number> million to ~<number> million are done within the bounds of respected academic study and reflect decades of work that builds upon the work of previous scholars and certainly does not willfully disregard documented evidence and recollections there are still plenty of questions within holocaust studies that are debated by scholars and there may still be more out there for us to discover and revise but when it comes to the basic facts there is simply no valid argument against them so what are the basics beginning with their rise to power in the s the nazi party headed by adolf hitler implemented a series of antijewish policies within germany marginalizing jews within society more and more stripping them of their wealth livelihoods and their dignity with the invasion of poland in <number> the number of jews under nazi control reached into the millions and this number would again increase with the invasion of the soviet union in <number> shortly after the invasion of poland the germans started to confine the jewish population into squalid ghettos after several plans on how to rid europe of the jews that all proved unfeasible by the time of the invasion of the soviet union in <number> ideological antisemitism and pragmatic resources considerations lead to masskillings becoming the only viable option in the minds of the nazi leadership first only practiced in the ussr it was influential groups such as the ss and the administration of the general government that pushed to expand the killing operations to all of europe and sometime at the end of <number> met with hitlers approval the early killings were carried out foremost by the einsatzgruppen paramilitary groups organized under the aegis of the ss and tasked with carrying out the mass killings of jews communists and other undesirable elements in the wake of the german militarys advance in what is often termed the holocaust by bullet the einsatzgruppen with the assistance of the wehrmacht the sd the security police as well as local collaborators would kill roughly two million persons over half of them jews most killings were carried out with mass shootings but other methods such as gas vans intended to spare the killers the trauma of shooting so many persons day after day were utilized too by early <number> the final solution to the socalled jewish question was essentially finalized at the wannsee conference under the direction of reinhard heydrich where the plan to eliminate the jewish population of europe using a series of extermination camps set up in occupied poland was presented and met with approval construction of extermination camps had already begun the previous fall and mass extermination mostly as part of operation reinhard had began operation by spring of <number> roughly <number> million persons nearly all jewish men women and children were immediately gassed upon arrival at bezec sobibor and treblinka over the next two years when these reinhard camps were closed and razed more victims would meet their fate in additional extermination camps such as chemno but most infamously at auschwitzbirkenau where slightly over <number> million persons mostly jews died under the plan set forth at wannsee exterminations were hardly limited to the jews of poland but rather jews from all over europe were rounded up and sent east by rail like cattle to the slaughter although the victims of the reinhard camps were originally buried they would later be exhumed and cremated and cremation of the victims was normal procedure at later camps such as auschwitz the camps there were two main types of camps run by nazi germany which is sometimes a source of confusion concentration camps were well known means of extrajudicial control implemented by the nazis shortly after taking power beginning with the construction of dachau in <number> political opponents of all type not just jews could find themselves imprisoned in these camps during the prewar years and while conditions were often brutal and squalid and numerous deaths did occur from mistreatment they were not usually a death sentence and the population fluctuated greatly although concentration camps were later made part of the final solution their purpose was not as immediate extermination centers some were way stations and others were work camps where germany intended to eke out every last bit of productivity from them through what was known as extermination through labor jews and other undesirable elements if deemed healthy enough to work could find themselves spared for a time and allowed to toil away like slaves until their usefulness was at an end although some concentration camps such as mauthausen did include small gas chambers mass gassing was not the primary purpose of the camp many camps becoming extremely overcrowded nevertheless resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of inhabitants due to the outbreak of diseases such as typhus or starvation all of which the camp administrations did little to prevent bergenbelsen which was not a work camp but rather served as something of a way station for prisoners of the camp systems being moved about is perhaps one of the most infamous of camps on this count saw some <number> deaths caused by the conditions often located in the reich camps liberated by the western forces were exclusively concentration camps and many survivor testimonies come from these camps the concentration camps are contrasted with the extermination camps which were purpose built for mass killing with large gas chambers and later on crematoria but little or no facilities for inmates often they were disguised with false facades to lull the new arrivals into a false sense of security even though rumors were of course rife for the fate that awaited the deportees almost all arrivals were killed upon arrival at these camps and in many cases the number of survivors numbered in the single digits such as at bezec where only seven jews forced to assist in operation of the camp were alive after the war several camps however were hybrids of both types the most famous being auschwitz which was vast a complex of subcamps the infamous selection of prisoners conducted by ss doctors upon arrival meant life or death with those deemed unsuited for labor immediately gassed and the more healthy and robust given at least temporary reprieve the death count at auschwitz numbered around <number> million but it is also the source of many survivor testimonies how do we know running through the evidence piece by piece would take more space than we have here but suffice to say there is a lot of evidence and not just the mountains of survivor testimony we have testimonies and writings from many who participated as well german documentation of the programs this site<url> catalogs some of the evidence we have for mass extermination as it relates to auschwitz below youll find a short list of excellent works that should help to introduce you to various aspects of holocaust study third reich trilogy<url> by richard evans hitler the germans and the final solution<url> by ian kershaw auschwitz a new history<url> by laurence rees ordinary men<url> by christopher browning denying the holocaust<url> by deborah e lipstadt askhistorians faqraskhistorianswikiwwiiwikinazigermany i am a bot and this action was performed automatically please contact the moderators of this subredditmessa

cleaned_text: its a bit difficult to give definitive answers here because the concept of slavery was much larger and more detailed than we think of in our modern presumably western minds there wasnt just one type of slave there wasnt just one type of slavery and multiple different types of both could exist within one part of greece and then we need to remember as well that these were mostly all independent places with their own laws customs etc additionally while some slaves could be owned by the state to use a term carefully they could also be privately owned what one owner does and and another does is often going to be different so slavery wasnt practiced the same way everywhere but for simplicities sake ill continue to use the term slave as a catchall there are depictions in the iconography which show slaves with beards but the problem with iconography is that it may not always reflect actual practices and sometimes we can only hypothesise that someone is a slave and unless theyve written something next to them to definitely say they are it can be difficult but youre right that hair was a very important cultural and social marker it was not only used to show positive things but also negative things women in particular were often marked for adultery or prostitution in this way so you would definitely see slaves having their hair shorn but it wouldnt have been every slave in every place

cleaned_text: folsom plano clovis etc are all culture designations its a way for archeologists and anthropologists to create broad groups for material evidence that we find many times we dont even have human bones at these sites its edged weapons animal bones or burnt seeds these cultures often overlapped and shared their technology so even these culture designations can be fluid and subjective we often dont know who occupied these sites they dont correspond to modern tribes for the few sites where there are human bones scientists are slowly sampling and sequencing where its possible this is complicated by indigenous peoples beliefs around their ancestors remains and american and canadian laws that protect those beliefsremains in the paper mentioned above the researchers were able to use previously sequenced dna from ancient native americans and compare it to <number> modern people from the blackfoot tribe they found that the blackfoot people have been in the area a very long time the tribe also seems to have been isolated for a long time as there was admixture they specifically mention the cree people but that admixture happened recently i assume most mixing happened after the trail of tears when several tribes were shoved together and marched west into the great plains i hope this helps

the holocaust includes these deaths or not is a matter of definitions but in no way a reflection on dispute that they occurred but this guy says otherwise unfortunately there is a small but vocal minority of persons who fall into the category of holocaust denial attempting to minimize the deaths by orders of magnitude impugn well proven facts or even claim that the holocaust is entirely a fabrication and never happened although they often selfstyle themselves as revisionists they are not correctly described by the title while revisionism is not inherently a dirty word actual revision to quote michael shermer entails refinement of detailed knowledge about events rarely complete denial of the events themselves and certainly not denial of the cumulation of events known as the holocaust it is absolutely true that were you to read a book written in <number> or so you would find information which any decent scholar today might reject and that is the result of good revisionism but these changes which even can be quite large such as the reassessment of deaths at auschwitz from ~<number> million to ~<number> million are done within the bounds of respected academic study and reflect decades of work that builds upon the work of previous scholars and certainly does not willfully disregard documented evidence and recollections there are still plenty of questions within holocaust studies that are debated by scholars and there may still be more out there for us to discover and revise but when it comes to the basic facts there is simply no valid argument against them so what are the basics beginning with their rise to power in the s the nazi party headed by adolf hitler implemented a series of antijewish policies within germany marginalizing jews within society more and more stripping them of their wealth livelihoods and their dignity with the invasion of poland in <number> the number of jews under nazi control reached into the millions and this number would again increase with the invasion of the soviet union in <number> shortly after the invasion of poland the germans started to confine the jewish population into squalid ghettos after several plans on how to rid europe of the jews that all proved unfeasible by the time of the invasion of the soviet union in <number> ideological antisemitism and pragmatic resources considerations lead to masskillings becoming the only viable option in the minds of the nazi leadership first only practiced in the ussr it was influential groups such as the ss and the administration of the general government that pushed to expand the killing operations to all of europe and sometime at the end of <number> met with hitlers approval the early killings were carried out foremost by the einsatzgruppen paramilitary groups organized under the aegis of the ss and tasked with carrying out the mass killings of jews communists and other undesirable elements in the wake of the german militarys advance in what is often termed the holocaust by bullet the einsatzgruppen with the assistance of the wehrmacht the sd the security police as well as local collaborators would kill roughly two million persons over half of them jews most killings were carried out with mass shootings but other methods such as gas vans intended to spare the killers the trauma of shooting so many persons day after day were utilized too by early <number> the final solution to the socalled jewish question was essentially finalized at the wannsee conference under the direction of reinhard heydrich where the plan to eliminate the jewish population of europe using a series of extermination camps set up in occupied poland was presented and met with approval construction of extermination camps had already begun the previous fall and mass extermination mostly as part of operation reinhard had began operation by spring of <number> roughly <number> million persons nearly all jewish men women and children were immediately gassed upon arrival at bezec sobibor and treblinka over the next two years when these reinhard camps were closed and razed more victims would meet their fate in additional extermination camps such as chemno but most infamously at auschwitzbirkenau where slightly over <number> million persons mostly jews died under the plan set forth at wannsee exterminations were hardly limited to the jews of poland but rather jews from all over europe were rounded up and sent east by rail like cattle to the slaughter although the victims of the reinhard camps were originally buried they would later be exhumed and cremated and cremation of the victims was normal procedure at later camps such as auschwitz the camps there were two main types of camps run by nazi germany which is sometimes a source of confusion concentration camps were well known means of extrajudicial control implemented by the nazis shortly after taking power beginning with the construction of dachau in <number> political opponents of all type not just jews could find themselves imprisoned in these camps during the prewar years and while conditions were often brutal and squalid and numerous deaths did occur from mistreatment they were not usually a death sentence and the population fluctuated greatly although concentration camps were later made part of the final solution their purpose was not as immediate extermination centers some were way stations and others were work camps where germany intended to eke out every last bit of productivity from them through what was known as extermination through labor jews and other undesirable elements if deemed healthy enough to work could find themselves spared for a time and allowed to toil away like slaves until their usefulness was at an end although some concentration camps such as mauthausen did include small gas chambers mass gassing was not the primary purpose of the camp many camps becoming extremely overcrowded nevertheless resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of inhabitants due to the outbreak of diseases such as typhus or starvation all of which the camp administrations did little to prevent bergenbelsen which was not a work camp but rather served as something of a way station for prisoners of the camp systems being moved about is perhaps one of the most infamous of camps on this count saw some <number> deaths caused by the conditions often located in the reich camps liberated by the western forces were exclusively concentration camps and many survivor testimonies come from these camps the concentration camps are contrasted with the extermination camps which were purpose built for mass killing with large gas chambers and later on crematoria but little or no facilities for inmates often they were disguised with false facades to lull the new arrivals into a false sense of security even though rumors were of course rife for the fate that awaited the deportees almost all arrivals were killed upon arrival at these camps and in many cases the number of survivors numbered in the single digits such as at bezec where only seven jews forced to assist in operation of the camp were alive after the war several camps however were hybrids of both types the most famous being auschwitz which was vast a complex of subcamps the infamous selection of prisoners conducted by ss doctors upon arrival meant life or death with those deemed unsuited for labor immediately gassed and the more healthy and robust given at least temporary reprieve the death count at auschwitz numbered around <number> million but it is also the source of many survivor testimonies how do we know running through the evidence piece by piece would take more space than we have here but suffice to say there is a lot of evidence and not just the mountains of survivor testimony we have testimonies and writings from many who participated as well german documentation of the programs this site<url> catalogs some of the evidence we have cleaned_text: we are always looking to find new answers its a requirement of the field we conduct whats called original research throughout our careers its a requirement to even get a phd and sometimes an ma original research should be something that no one has done before but it usually isnt like hey i discovered a country no one knew existed but smaller in scope like this vase type may have been made by a similar artist that worked in this other area as evident by the use of a specific stroke that no one noticed before i wouldnt say theres anything as big as consciousness but certainly large areas of debate because we are constantly publishing new ideas and new original research we may run into conflict and usually do with someone elses hypothesis they might look at that vase type that one person argued was a similar artist and say its actually proof of a brand new unidentified artist because it looks like the stroke was done by a left hand while the other one was right etc over time the left and right crowds will debate and eventually there will be some consensus for the most part theres still some big quests like translating linear a finding alexander the greats tomb etc but its a lot of small pieces of evidence and small steps and it takes a lot of time and for the most part never makes the news because its quite boring to most people one question thats mostly been answered but was debated for a long time with great arguments from both sides is who invented the trireme you can go down that track if you want to see what this sort of argument looked like and how it slowly got solved
label: r/history

cleaned_text: difficulty is that we have the tools they used big heavy projectile points are worthless against small game and extravagantly wasteful against medium sized things skinned game like deer there is a reason why they had them there are all kinds of ways you can hunt large dangerous and thickskinned prey in relative safety though dying on a hunt was probably a regular occurrence for example you can attack from a position at a choke point or from elevated terrain where the animals cant get to you ive seen this done by bow hunters going after african elephants you could also panic them into stampeding perhaps by setting a wildfire and they might not even notice theyve been hit initially just from the adrenaline or if they do might not have noticed their attacker or judged that sticking around to stomp thag simpson for hurting them is a bad idea risking being burnt to death also remember this isnt about individual hunters no one person can process an elephant regardless of how shaggy it is it would have been a whole tribe effort also even thick skinned game like elephants can be effectively killed with primitive weaponry they kill differently than firearms yes firearms destroy tissue by crushing this is why the ability of a bullet to kill is dominated by <number>mv^<number> arrows spears and atlatl darts kill by cutting tissue not crushing it you dont need nearly as much energy plus youre making assumptions about what an extinct animal will do based upon living species we know african elephants can be aggressive when attacked or disturbed but african wildlife is like that because of all of the predators and aggressive herbivores asian elephants can also be aggressive but they are not as aggressive as their cousins on the dark continent we simply dont know how mammoths and mastodons would have reacted implicit in the argument you are making is that because you cant imagine a way to hunt mammoths safely without modern firearms our ancestors couldnt either also the assumption that they cared for their personal individual safety as much as first world modern technological humans do today i think both are facially invalid assumptions and actually rather insulting there is a kind of haughty derision behind your post that because our ancestors had primitive technology that they werent as intelligent as we are today this is erich von danikenlevel cleaned_text: again lack of imagination first of all they were probably using atlatls to throw their spears actually the terminology is darts we have atlatl weights from the time period for example and you need the extra leverage to throw a dart a significant distance the darts would have had a removable foreshaft with the projectile point because the points are relatively fragile and break easily on vigorous contact with a hard surface like a rock and sometimes even bone being able to easily replace the point on a dart or an arrow is why foreshafts are used atlatls also allow you quite a bit of extra range more than you might imagine current world record for the javelin is about <number> meters world record for an atlatl dart is <number> meters im not suggesting that our ancestors shot at mammoths from <number>+ yards but it gives you an idea of the relative distance between throwing a spear and throwing an atlatl dart if you can throw a hunting spear <number> meters you can probably do <number> meters with an equivalent dart and its not just one person youve got a group of men all launching darts at manny the mammoth probably spread out fairly evenly and if the mammoth goes after thag ogg and tumak and the boys are going to be attacking him from the sides all it takes is one dart to penetrate into the lungs to eventually kill the mammoth and thats a pretty big target yeah modern technology allows a single individual to go up against an elephant with relatively little danger but a group of individuals with primitive technology can also be effective btw have you ever made stone tools and projectile points i have im not good enough to make a clovis or folsom point but i have made smaller pieces and you wouldnt believe how unbelievably sharp they are far sharper than any steel blade for hunting something like deer small bird points are perfectly adequate there is a reason why people back then made relatively huge and technically difficult to make points to hunt very large thickskinned game

india we are told accounted for roughly <number> of world gdp in <number> before british rule falling to a minuscule <number> per cent when the british left in <number> what that glib comparison overlooks is the fact that india in <number> also had <number> per cent of the worlds population meaning that its per capita gdp the real measure of prosperity was relatively low due to its poor productivity as a largely agrarian economy on the eve of global industrialisation which exponentially multiplied world gdp indeed per capita income had been declining since <number> when the mughal empire arguably peaked under its most illustrious emperor akbar according to the maddison project the major drop in indias per capita gdp occurred between <number> and <number> and was stagnant thanks to british indias rajinspired industrial revolution but dropped again to <cur><number> in <number> due to the world recession after ww the reasons for indias historically low productivity were manifold textiles indias main export were already declining in the s because its labourintensive technology was unable to compete with europes more technologically innovative handloom sector underlying mughal indias technological stagnation was the fact that no agricultural surplus was being reinvested because it was instead being creamed off by a rentier feudal class because wages levels were low in india producers preferred to increase output by hiring more workers rather than investing in new technology an estimated <number> per cent of the mughal empire was not administered directly but farmed out to feudal taxcollectors known as jagirdars in return for military service jagirdars were only appointed for a few years at a time with the result that their prime incentive was to extract as much from their districts as possible as quickly as possible with minimal longterm investment in new technology or irrigation the resulting decline in mughal agricultural productivity pushed up both food and textile prices thereby adding to the loss of foreign market share although india now had to compete in rapidly expanding world markets due to the industrial revolution in western europe mughal india unlike europe had neither autonomous cities nor a merchant class strong enough to offset these agrarian parasites at the peak of the raj the british rulers were a very thin off but under the mughal regime the equivalent group had collected <number> of national income in taxes and spent most of it on their own consumption the leading historian of mughal india irfan habib concludes that not only was the mughal empire its own gravedigger but no new order was or could be created by the forces ranged against it the political collapse of the mughal empire resulted in an even less economically conducive state of affairs though not literally anarchy it was a disintegration into regional warlordism with predictable results the collapse of imperial authority resulted in what economic historians have identified as a period of deindustrialization much before the dominance of the east india company imperial decline and constant internecine warfare reduced agricultural land acreage and productivity which drove up food prices then nominal wages and then textile prices in an inflationary chain reaction which cost india textile market share in britain even before the latter developed factory technology wrongly blamed for that decline between <number> and <number> the loss of mughal hegemony allowed new despotic rulers to revenue farm their conquered populations cleaned_text: you know i didnt spend nearly enough time thinking about either of those groups mainly because theyre somewhat peripheral to the main story but i did spend a lot of time thinking about the murfree brood another group of murderous isolated folks i came to the conclusion that these guys are cut from the cloth of the worst stereotypes of southern appalachia rather than actual history itself theyre pulled from movies like deliverance <number> more than anything else as i explain in the book there was a really long campaign across the us to make white southern mountain people look exotic backward different and preserved in amber the obsession with rural violence is part of that but ultimately this myth was invented rather than real and it was really propagated in order to justify the siphoning of wealth from the mountains outward mainly coal and timber was the us west unusually violent in the late s some places were in boom towns where you had a lot of strangers flooding in especially when it was mainly men from a range of racialethnic groups violence tended to be more common there were fewer social bonds preventing violence and bullets often flew as a result the homicide rates in some of these towns was as high as <number> per <number> which is way higher than any us cities today but many pockets of the west were really tame and tranquil with very low violence rates especially where the population was more homogenous and the balance of women and men was more equal

cleaned_text: so i actually devote three chapters of my book to butcher creek because i think its a standin for southern appalachia ie west virginia eastern kentucky eastern tennessee western north carolina etc this was a region that was torn apart by big corporations from outside the region in this very era which produced a ton of ill effects for local residents deforestation destroyed peasant economies in the woods and coal mining in company towns shortened life spans as well overall i think rdr has a dr jekyllmr hyde take on southern appalachia on one hand they recycle all of the most tired stereotypes of the region with its bearded archaic uneducated trappedinamber hillbillies who are isolated from american progress but then it also shows how wall street ie leviticus cornwall was tearing asunder the region in pursuit of wealth so i play around with that duality a lot in the book

cleaned_text: such a great question so the american diet was changing really quickly in the late s with the rise of massive food processors like the chicago meatpackers swift armour morris etc and these new titans of industry began selling new foods that americans had never seen before mainly to get rid of their waste products and earn a dime in the process consider oleomargarine processed beef tallow with salt and yellow coloring added so that it would resemble butter but way grosser they even marketed it by deceptive names like butterine to try to trick folks into buying it same goes for canned beef another disgusting byproduct of the chicago packinghouses have you heard of upton sinclairs famous book the jungle <number> it was a hugely influential book and led to the passing of the pure food and drug act soon thereafter given that rdr is set a few years before that act i think selling something like salted offal would have been totally realistic but i bet the chicago packers would have called it by some more deceptively appetizing name but yes processed industrial foods in this era were often disgusting people ate it because it was cheap and they didnt have that many other options especially poor urban folks

cleaned_text: hey so the national audubon society was founded in <number> so just after rdr and they were all about bird preservation and habitat protection though many shot birds too to paint and admire them so there was clearly a movement budding at the time what i find a bit paradoxical about rdr though is that it portrays rural america as this place teeming with wildlife almost as an edenic garden untouched by humanity thats really far from the truth the s were actually a terrible time to be a wild animal the bison was on the verge of extinction with only a few hundred left alive and the passenger pigeon a bird that had literally darkened the skies with their massive flocks in the earlier years of the s had gone extinct around the turn of the century the american landscape was in many ways gutted and denuded at that moment that is what spurred the national parks and conservation movements in large part

cleaned_text: i have read many histories and narratives on this subject and there is reason to be skeptical while there are instances where a collective group of slaves may work together on a specific scheme to steal food or even beatkill an overseer or even rarely a master the development of a communication system like this is unlikely black slaves were not a uniformed collection of brothers and sisters united in solidarity the institution was setup to ensure they werent for every <number> slaves there were two who legitimately loved their white folk the slave next to you could be sold tomorrow why be loyal to him in short masters would know every part of that system prohibit its use and punish anyone using it snitching was very real and very common youd have to get past a boss the highest ranking mean black slave and the twofaced old slaves who were paid in food and candy while slaves were in bondage theoretically they werent always in bondage and in a position to want to escape a plantation was an ordered system around forced labor that people were born into the typical mindset evaluated ones condition by how much the master kept up his part of the arrangement food seasonal clothes medical care housing arrangement time offleisure time and whether the overseers were allowed to be brutal when the yankees came many opted to stay after the war many including my family on both sides opted to be sharecroppers my white folks was good to me is common in many of the slave narratives i say this to say that these urban legends come about because americans black and white refuse to think critically about the brainwashing involved in the institution sure you had patrols slave catchers and bounty hunters but the system on the plantation including your kin made a systemic strategy to run away all of the time nowhere in the common slaves psyche they couldnt envision a change of order unless they were kidnapped or separated from the family via sale or gift

cleaned_text: the us did not intend to have a standing army they would only be called up when needed as they viewed standing armies as tools of oppressors boston massacre quartering act etc instead militias would act as local defense in response to immediate action which would give towns and cities further down the road time to prepare and a wider call up of troops if necessary this is viewable in the original text >a well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed when the british invaded one of the first things they did in certain areas was go after the gun powder supplies these were rally points where local militias would go and get the supplies they needed besides those kept at home ensuring people could still have militias to defend the area against tyrannical peoples including their own government was seen as necessary in reaction to the ongoing revolution against the colonies government this was written with revolution in mind personal rights of gun ownership were of course something as well but that sort of thing wasnt really heavily debated at this point there would be no real need to tell people they could have guns because of course they could

cleaned_text: > they didnt make a distinction between someone being trans bisexual or even just into crossdressing they were just tried as homosexuals thats not true you were tried as a homosexual specifically if you were a preoperational trans woman who had sexual relations with men in that time transness was mostly diagnosed as a type of intersex disorder and hirschfeld also saw homosexuality as a type of intersexuality but they were aware of distinctions between the groups hirschfeld introduced a type of legal recognition of transgender people called transvestitenpass and while the usage definitely greatly decreased during the nazi era mostly because most of them were given out by hirschfelds institute which was majorly jewish there are multiple documented cases of people receiving them after the nazi takeover and the police respecting them another relatively high famous case was heinrich rathjen who was likely intersex heinrich was born as dora and competed for germany as a woman at the <number> olympics his intersex status became known in the late s and he was allowed to transition to male under nazi rule we also have naziera documents about the trans women who received sex change operations under hirschfeld in the s and as far as i know all of them were treated as fully female legally by the nazis also despite the fact that their transitions were widely reported in the newspapers at the time and none faced prosecution for being trans also unfun fact the doctor who performed the first known vaginoplasty later performed forced medical experiments on prisoners at the dachau concentration camp similarly cross dressing was technically illegal unless you had a transvestitenpass but in practice this was only enforced if it was in a homosexual context for example wehrmacht soldiers actually took photos of themselves cross dressing relatively often<url>

cleaned_text: depends on which parts of the subcontinent by the time the battle of plassey took place the mughal empire was basically a puppet the muslim durrani empire and predominantly hindu maratha empire were still struggling over control of delhi the city that the mughal empire used as their capital when the power vacuum continued it was temporarily filled by the sikh empire under maharaja ranjit singh its very difficult to answer counterfactuals in history any question that involves if x had not happened then z would havewould not have happened though most histories ive read suggest that the mughals declined after emperor akbar was murdered and instead of continuing his policy of religious tolerance his successors decided to antagonize their nonmuslim subjects by doubling down on religious supremacism and pissed away the empires treasury on wars of conquest its plausible that some regions of india would have stayed under the control of muslim sultans but again even without british military intervention there were signs that the central muslim power in india represented by the mughal empire was on the way out and being actively challenged by their former hindu and sikh subjects

cleaned_text: i apologizei didnt take the time to refresh myself properly and youre right akbar was not murdered according to a brief skim of the internet it seems he suspected his successor salim of trying to poison him but i concede that nothing ive found implies akbar was killed as for the comment about religious antagonism ive taken the time to look into it and i was thinking of emperor aurangzeb i wish i was able to go back and find the specific academic source but the general story i was told is that aurangzeb was highly preoccupied with conquestthough there appears to be ongoing debate amongst modern historians as to whether aurangzebs conquests actually sparked an economic crisis or to what extent he actually enforced muslim law over the nonmuslim religious communities in the mughal empire clearly my professors favored one side of the debate over the other aurangzeb did order the execution of sikh guru tegh bahadur though again sources conflict over the moral basis mughal sources accused guru tegh bahadur of banditry whereas sikh sources claim the guru was executed for refusing aurangzebs demands to give up the sikh faith indian history is in my opinion very unusual in terms of how much disagreement and debate there is over what events are connected by cause and effect or just coincidence its not a case of peerreviewed academics on one side vs ignorantbutnoisy tinfoil hatters on the other but deep divisions where groups of respected academics still cant reach a consensus on what caused what or why however specific times and sequences of events are things that historians can at least agree on most of the time ill at least stand by my earlier position while this is purely speculation the mughal empire had fallen heavily into disarray without direct involvement by the east india company dont get me wrong the battle of plassey was disastrous for the mughals but the mughals were on a losing streak long before that the rapid rise of both the maratha empiremaratha confederation and the vibrant but shortlived sikh empire in my opinion serve as evidence that the eic werent the only nonmuslim power capable of filling the power vacuum the mughals left behind

cleaned_text: just to respond to the last part of the question the decision to switch from the raf airfields to bombing london was made by goering and wasnt something forced by the british for context prior to this theyd been an accidental hit on london by a lost german bomber which provoked a very small tit for tat raid on berlin that caused nothing in the way of damage but this wasnt the main driver behind his decision a constant overestimate by luftwaffe pilots over how many planes they had shot down had convinced the germans that the raf couldnt have many more planes left yet time was running out for an invasion as the weather would get too bad in october and the germans still hadnt gained the needed air superiority in the south of england for the invasion to go ahead goering believed that if he launched bombing raids on london the raf would have to come out and fight as opposed to husbanding their resources which they had been doing all summer and his fighters could then clean up thus clearing the skies for the invasion to go ahead of course this didnt quite turn out how the germans expected with the invasion no longer an option until spring the germans opted for strategic night bombing attacking british cities across the country from september <number> to march <number> in the hope that the british would sue for peace the indiscriminate results of which so delighted the germans they actually invented a new verb following the attack on coventry coventrieren to devastate a city by bombing shirer covers this quite well in his rise and fall of the third reich so social media is incorrect bomber command did not attack first indeed prior to the summer of <number> it had mainly been dropping leaflets over germany laying mines or attacking shipping the only instance prior to postblitz that i am aware of and could be regarded as a british strategic bombing attack was a small force that attacked some oil plants following the bombing of rotterdam in may <number> as sir arthur harris said the nazis entered this war under the rather childish delusion that they were going to bomb everyone else and nobody was going to bomb them at rotterdam london warsaw and half a hundred other places they put their rather naive theory into operation they sowed the wind and now they are going to reap the whirlwind

cleaned_text: i had the opportunity to attend a wonderful lecture by one of the first research groups to challenge the collapse story about the island it was really impressive how much meticulous work they had done to dig into diamonds various claims including some seriously impressive work on how the heads were carved and some really great forensive anthropology on the question of why one of the points they made was that it is pretty tenuous to only look at authoritative written textual sources to determine first european contact with the islands population since it was a pretty widely accepted fact that european civilian ships would often not log every single landfall or necessarily provide clear indications of where they had landed diamond essentially argued that since there was no european contact until x year clearly the population must have collapsed of its own accord prior to that but that only works if you assume that the only contact was recorded in unambiguous written textual sources if you question that dubious assumption then it is entirely possible and even likely that earlier contact and therefore disease transmission was the main cause of population collapse

cleaned_text: yes starting around the th century the reason british sailors are called limeys is bc of the limes they carried on board to reduce scurvy in the th century british sailors had a specific lime ration on their trips bc of this roses lime juice was invented for this and its still available at most grocery stores for making gimlets the link between fresh fruit and scurvy was known in the th century but it wasnt really a big problem until people really started sailing long distances in the th century the spanish and portuguese recommended carrying citrus bc of its effectiveness the actual mechanism of scurvy wasnt discovered until the s stephen brown has a great book on the history of scurvy and talks about some of the issues like when lime juice is exposed to light the chemical hexuronic acid that combats scurvy breaks down so people would drink lime juice and it wouldnt always work which made fresh fruit uncertain as a cure his book is just called scurvy <url> the new david grann book the wager details the shipwreck of the wager in the s and they experience scurvy on that trip its a great book and worth reading for a bunch of reasons but if youre interested in scurvy its a good jumping off point

cleaned_text: i dont really know that the article proves its point ive seen most of these before and heres the thing the bow was already being phased out when many of the sources this article cites are mentioned those at the beginning that is a few sources arguing for the bow arent really all that meaningful in wwii there was a significant debate about how best to battle massed tank formations deployed guns vs selfpropelled guns the us army heavily favored deployed at first but selfpropelled guns won out if you just randomly cited lesley mcnair you might think the opposite but just because mcnair favored deployed guns and made sensible sounding arguments in their favor does not mean selfpropelled guns didnt win that doctrinal debate same thing with the us armys latter debated on battle rifles vs semiautomatic rifles many favored the former well past the point it just didnt make sense their arguments werent random or incoherent but they were nonetheless not born out by the reality of experience at the time id also point out in the premise theres a bit of a switcheroo the oft opinioned internet wisdom is that guns took less time to train you could call that easier but thats not an argument that muskets took off because you could hand them to a mob and get results this is also the point the article spends no real time debunking it quotes a single person who i can immediately point out is not doing a very good job separating topics the professionalization of military forces in europe goes hand in hand with the adoption of gun but the costs of professionalization should not be confused with the costs of arms training nor does one strictly bear on the other the article kind of glosses over its own problem in this regard untrained bands of bowmen and such in countries were weekend training on your own time was a norm vs the states adoption of a more direct hand in training professional troops that they didnt have to train the former directly would seem to be a consequence of the very laws the article brings up not the debunking point it tries to make per se the op article never actually argues this point instead it focuses on the economics of training and whether or not training was important at all which isnt the argument people repeat ie the article first declares an argument is false but then argues against a strawman instead the article then proceeds to make economic arguments that i dont think pan out at least they dont vibe with what ive read so im skeptical of the contextless numbers provided to argue against the strawman argument that isnt the argument the article proclaims to be debunking this article is a bit too fast and loose and cherry picked to really convince me the conventional wisdom is wrong id also point out <number> citations at the end is not tons of sources of the three only one looks scholarly and its contents arent directly addressed also i swear i saw this exact post like <number> months ago on raskhistorians almost word for word technically they both lost because tactics around tanks and antitank warfare took unforeseen turns in the late s and early s
